column1: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a self-contained defibrillator device designed to be movable
column2: and easy and simple to use. They are often shaped like briefcases so that they can be carried by a handle. An AED contains a battery
column4: and electrodes. When the electrodes are stuck onto the patient
column5: the control computer will assess the patient
column6: checking the rhythm of their heart. It will then charge itself to an appropriate power level and tell users that the person needs to be shocked. If the patient does not need to be defibrillated
column7: the automated external defibrillator will not allow a shock to be administered. A button must still be pushed manually to trigger the shock
column8: as the operator beforehand must be certain that nobody is touching the patient. Often
